questions.text: A 28-year-old woman delivers two babies. One is fully developed, while the other shows a gestational age difference of about 2 months. Which of the following best explains this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Marked gestational age difference between twins suggests superfoetation, where a second ovum is fertilised in a later menstrual cycle during an existing pregnancy.

Superfoetation:

  • Fertilisation of a second ovum in a woman already pregnant.
  • Two foetuses may be born:
    • At the same time, but with different developmental stages, or
    • Fully developed, born 1-3 months apart.
  • More likely in a bipartite or double uterus.

Superfecundation: (Option A)

  • Fertilisation of two ova released in the same cycle by two separate acts of coitus at short intervals.
  • Twin pregnancy incidence: ~1.5%; 70% are binovular (separate fertilisation of two ova).
  • Twin development is parallel but unequal, depending on blood supply.
  • Both ova may not mature; one foetus may be aborted early or die.
  • A dead foetus may become foetus compressus or foetus papyraceus. (Option C)
  • Spermatozoa may come from different men.

Explanation of other options:

Fecundation ab extra (Option D): Fertilisation from sperm deposited outside the vaginal introitus, unrelated to gestational age difference in twins.

choices.text: A man penetrates his penis into the vagina of a woman without her consent.
A man applies his mouth to the vagina of a woman against her will.
Sexual intercourse by a man with a 17-year-old woman, with her consent.
Insertion of an instrument into the vagina of a woman during a medical procedure.

questions.text: Under Section 63 BNS, which of the following is not considered rape?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Medical procedure or intervention is specifically excluded under the exceptions to Section 63 BNS.

Section 63 BNS - Definition of Rape

A man is said to commit "rape" if he does any of the following acts:

Acts constituting rape:

  1. Penetration by penis: Penetrates his penis, to any extent, into the vagina, mouth, urethra, or anus of a woman, or makes her do so with him or any other person. (Option A)
  2. Insertion of object/body part: Inserts, to any extent, any object or a part of the body (not being the penis) into the vagina, urethra, or anus of a woman, or makes her do so with him or any other person.
  3. Manipulation causing penetration: Manipulates any part of the body of a woman to cause penetration into the vagina, urethra, anus, or any part of the body of such woman, or makes her do so with him or any other person.
  4. Oral application: Applies his mouth to the vagina, anus, or urethra of a woman, or makes her do so with him or any other person. (Option B)

Circumstances under which it amounts to rape:

The above acts amount to rape when committed:

  • Against her will.
  • Without her consent.
  • With her consent, when consent was obtained by putting her or any person she is interested in under fear of death or hurt.
  • With her consent, when the man knows he is not her husband and she consents because she believes he is another man to whom she is or believes herself lawfully married.
  • With her consent, when she is unable to understand the nature and consequences of the act due to unsoundness of mind, intoxication, or administration of stupefying/unwholesome substances by him or another.
  • With or without her consent, when she is under 18 years of age. (Option D)
  • When she is unable to communicate consent.

Exceptions:

  • Medical procedure or intervention is not rape.
  • Sexual intercourse or sexual acts by a man with his wife (wife not being under 15 years of age) is not rape.

questions.text: Which section of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) lays down the punishment for rape?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Section 64(1) BNS lays down the punishment for the offence of rape.

choices.text: A woman who is in an intoxicated state
His wife is living under a decree of separation
Any person other than his wife
A girl below 18 years of age even with her consent

questions.text: For a man to be found guilty of statutory rape, he must have had sexual intercourse with?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Statutory Rape:

  • Sexual intercourse with a girl below 18 years of age is considered statutory rape, regardless of her consent.
  • It is neither violent nor physically coercive, but still constitutes rape by law due to the girl's age.

choices.text: The husband can be punished under Section 67 BNS.
The wife's consent is necessary for lawful sexual intercourse when living separately.
Sexual intercourse with the wife living separately without her consent is not punishable.
The punishment includes imprisonment for a term of at least 2 years.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman files a complaint alleging that her husband raped her while they were living separately under a decree of separation. Which of the following statements is false regarding this situation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sexual intercourse without consent while living separately is punishable under Section 67 of the BNS.

Marital Rape:

  • Forceful sexual intercourse with a wife who is living separately from her husband (under a decree of separation or otherwise) without her consent is considered marital rape. (Option B & C)
  • It includes sexual intercourse without consent, even if separation is by custom or usage.

Section 67, BNS: (Option A)

  • Whoever has sexual intercourse with his wife who is living separately (under a decree of separation or otherwise) without her consent,
  • Shall be punished with imprisonment of at least 2 years, which may extend up to 7 years, (Option D)
  • And shall also be liable to a fine.

questions.text: A superior officer in a police department induces his female subordinate to have sexual intercourse by promising her a promotion. After receiving the promotion, the subordinate files a complaint of sexual exploitation. Under which section of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) is the superior officer liable?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Section 376C IPC deals specifically with sexual intercourse by a person in authority, like a superior officer, obtained by misuse of power or inducement such as a promise of promotion.

Section 376C, IPC - Sexual Offence by Person in Authority or Fiduciary Relationship

  • Whoever, being any of the following persons:
    • a) In a position of authority or fiduciary relationship;
    • b) A public servant;
    • c) Superintendent or manager of a jail, remand home, or any place of custody, or a women's or children's institution;
    • d) On the management of a hospital or being a staff member of a hospital,
  • Abuses of such a position or a fiduciary relationship to
    • Induce or seduce any woman who is either in his custody, under his charge, or present on the premises,
    • To have sexual intercourse with him,
  • Where such sexual intercourse does not amount to the offence of rape,
    • Shall be punished with:
      • Rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 5 years, which may extend to 10 years,
      • And shall also be liable to a fine.

Explanation of other options:

Section 354 IPC (Option B): Deals with assault or criminal force to a woman with the intent to outrage her modesty, but does not specifically cover sexual intercourse or misuse of authority for sexual exploitation.

Section 375 IPC (Option C): Defines general rape but does not specifically address sexual intercourse obtained by a person in a position of authority through inducement or misuse of power.

Section 506 IPC (Option D): Pertains to criminal intimidation and threats, which is unrelated to sexual exploitation or intercourse obtained by inducement.

choices.text: Inheritance of property by the child
Compensation case for slander against the mother

questions.text: Which of the following legal issues are involved in the case of a posthumous child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Posthumous Child:

  • Child born after the death of its father.
  • The mother was conceived by the deceased father before his death.
  • Legal Issues Involved:
    • Legitimacy of the child. (Option A)
    • Inheritance of property by the child. (Option B)
    • Compensation case for slander against the mother. (Option C)

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl reports to the police that a family friend has been repeatedly making sexually inappropriate remarks and touching her inappropriately over the past few months. The family friend holds a trusted position in the community. Under the POCSO Act, which of the following offences is MOST likely applicable in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The offence involves a trusted individual (family friend) committing sexual misconduct, which qualifies as an aggravated sexual offence under POCSO.

POCSO Act 2012:

  • A law to protect children from sexual offences, harassment, and child pornography.
  • Safeguards a child's interest at all stages of legal proceedings: lodging police report, recording evidence, investigations, and quick trials in designated courts.
  • Defines a child as any individual below 18 years of age, irrespective of gender.

Types of Sexual Crimes against Children under POCSO:

  1. Sexual Assault: (Option A)
    • Includes the bad touch of a child.
    • Punishment: Minimum 3 years imprisonment, extendable up to 5 years, plus fine.
  2. Aggravated Sexual Offence: (Option B)
    • Sexual offence committed by a trusted individual (relative, police, public servant, hospital or school staff).
    • Punishment: Imprisonment of 5 to 7 years, plus fine.
  3. Penetrative Sexual Offence:
    • Involves penetration.
    • Punishment: Minimum 7 years imprisonment, extendable to life imprisonment, plus fine.
  4. Aggravated and Penetrative Sexual Offence:
    • Penetrative offence by a person in a position of trust.
    • Includes grievous offences like repeated assault on a child below 12 years.
    • Punishment: Minimum 10 years imprisonment, extendable to life imprisonment, plus fine.
  5. Sexually Oriented Harassment: (Option C)
    • Includes sexually oriented remarks, offensive gestures, flashing, etc.
    • Punishment: 3 years imprisonment, plus a fine.
  6. Child Pornography: (Option D)
    • Use of children in pornography.
    • Punishment: Imprisonment up to 5 years, plus fine.

References:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC11668369/#sec12

choices.text: Hymenal tears extend posteriorly into the perineal body and may involve the anorectal canal
Tears are limited to the external genitalia with no involvement of deeper structures
The hymen remains intact due to its high elasticity in young children
Vaginal vault rupture is uncommon and never associated with abdominal viscera herniation

questions.text: In cases of penile penetration in young children, which of the following injury patterns is most commonly observed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Penetration typically causes posterior hymenal tears extending into the perineal body and often involves the anorectal canal, reflecting deeper injury beyond just superficial genitalia.

Pediatric Sexual Abuse:

  • The hymen is torn posteriorly as the penis enters the vagina.
  • Additional pressure causes the hymenal tear to extend into or through the perineal body, often involving the anterior wall of the anorectal canal. (Option A & C)
  • In younger children, the labia majora tissues are more prominent and more prone to contusions, abrasions, and lacerations, especially in the anterior half.
  • Circumferential tears of the vestibular mucosa are common in young children.
  • Full penile penetration causes extensive hematoma, mainly affecting the anterior half.
  • Tears frequently involve both anterior and posterior vaginal walls.
  • Anterior tears may involve the bladder.
  • Posterior tears may involve the anorectal canal. (Option B)
  • The vaginal vault may rupture, sometimes with herniation of abdominal viscera. (Option D)
  • The hymen may be destroyed or show lacerations.
  • Bleeding is brisk from the skin and mucosa, but may be slight from the perineal body.
  • There may be mucopurulent vaginal discharge.
  • Attempts to separate the thighs for examination cause severe pain due to local inflammation.
  • The child may have difficulty walking due to pain.

choices.text: In virginity, the hymen is loose and elastic with a wide opening allowing passage of multiple fingers.
In defloration, the labia majora are not apposed, and the vaginal orifice may be visible.
The fossa navicularis is intact in virginity but disappears after defloration.
The fourchette may be torn or intact after defloration.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about virginity and defloration is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In virginity, the hymen is intact, rigid, and inelastic, with a narrow opening hardly allowing even a small finger to pass.

questions.text: Within what time must the practitioner take a vaginal swab to maximise the chance of detecting spermatozoa after sexual assault?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Spermatozoa detection rates significantly decrease if the vaginal swab is collected later than 72 hours (3 days) after the assault.

Genital Swab Technique in Sexual Assault Victims:

  • The genital swab technique is the preferred method for specimen collection in adult sexual assault cases.
  • Using genital swab preparation can increase the spermatozoa detection rate by 6%.
  • In some cases, collection of both swab and slide specimens may be considered.
  • Collecting specimens more than 3 days after the assault significantly decreases the spermatozoa detection rate.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4637504/
  2. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1752928X15001468

questions.text: On medical examination of a sexual assault victim, motile sperm are detected in the vaginal smear. Within what time frame has the assault most likely occurred?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mobile sperm in the vagina can usually be detected up to 6-12 hours after sexual intercourse.

Motility of Sperms:

  • When semen is kept at room temperature:
    • Full motility persists for about 3 hours.
    • 50% of sperm remain motile by 8 hours.
    • 10% remain motile by 24 hours.
  • In living persons, motile sperm are usually seen up to 6 hours and rarely up to 12 hours after ejaculation into the vagina.
  • Sperm mobility in the female genital tract is approximately 1 to 4 mm per minute.
  • Complete sperm can be seen up to 26 hours after intercourse, occasionally up to 2 to 3 days.
  • Broken sperm may be found up to:
    • One week in the vagina and cervix.
    • One to two weeks in the uterus.
  • After death:
    • Intact sperm may be found up to 2 days in the vagina.
    • Up to one week in the cervix and uterus.

choices.text: The person has engaged in a sexual act recently
The person has not engaged in a sexual act in the last 24 hours
The person has not engaged in a sexual act in the last 48 hours
The person has not engaged in a sexual act in the last 1 week

questions.text: While examining a man accused of rape, you observe the presence of smegma on his corona glandis. Which of the following can be inferred from this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of smegma indicates no sexual intercourse has occurred in the last 24 hours, since intercourse removes smegma, and it takes about 24 hours to accumulate.

Smegma:

  • If the accused is not circumcised, the foreskin may be retracted.
  • The presence or absence of smegma (a cheesy secretion from sebaceous glands, consisting mainly of desquamated epithelial cells) on the corona glandis should be noted.
  • The absence of smegma may indicate that intercourse might have been performed.
  • The presence of smegma rules out the possibility of complete penetration, because smegma gets rubbed off during intercourse.
  • Smegma will also be removed by bathing or washing.
  • Smegma usually requires about 24 hours to collect.

choices.text: Funnel-shaped anus as a common feature
Absence of fine wrinkles in anal mucosa

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common finding in a habitual passive agent of anal intercourse?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A funnel-shaped anus is very rare and usually an anatomical variant, not a common finding in habitual passive agents.

Signs of a Habitual Passive Agent (Sodomy):

  • Shaving of anal hair. (Option A)
  • Skin around the anus becomes smooth and thickened, extending into the anal canal up to the mucocutaneous junction, sometimes reaching the upper anal canal.
  • Loss of anal muscle tone, the anus does not contract readily when the surrounding skin is pinched. (Option B)
  • Slight depression of the buttocks towards the anus due to absorption of fat.
  • A funnel-shaped anus is very rare and usually an anatomical variant. (Option C)
  • Dilatation and laxity of the anus with epithelialisation of wrinkled mucosa in the area.
    • Lax (overstretched) anus is significant.
    • Elastic (capable of dilation) anus has no value diagnostically.
  • Presence of anal fissures, scars, etc.
  • Absence of fine wrinkles in the anal mucosa. (Option D)
  • Piles and fissures are very common in elderly sodomists.
  • Presence of venereal disease.

Lateral Buttock Traction Test:

  • Method: Thumbs on each side of the anus, lateral traction applied.
  • Normal: Anal sphincter reflexly contracts.
  • Habitual sodomite: Sphincter relaxed, anal opening dilates 4-5 cm, rectum visible.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man enjoys dressing as a woman, adopts feminine mannerisms, and reports occasional sexual pleasure from cross-dressing without hormonal or genital abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario of dressing in opposite-sex clothing for identity and occasional sexual pleasure without hormonal or genital abnormalities indicates transvestism.

Transvestism / Eonism:

  • A condition where a person's whole personality is dominated by the desire to be identified and thought of as a member of the opposite sex.
  • Characteristics:
    • Dress, manner, occupational interests, and associations are aimed at increasing the feeling of being a woman (in males).
    • Sexuality is relatively unimportant, except when it promotes feelings of femininity.
  • Occurrence:
    • Usually found in males.
    • They may obtain sexual pleasure by wearing female dress.
  • Psychological basis:
    • May depend on erotic attraction to the opposite sex.
    • Only a small percentage are homosexuals.
    • Rarely develops from fetishistic interest in clothing or specific body parts of the opposite sex.
  • Physical findings:
    • No hormonal disturbances or genital abnormalities.

Explanation of other options:

Transsexualism (Option A): Characterised by a persistent desire to live as the opposite gender, often seeking hormonal or surgical transition, not just cross-dressing.

Frotteurism (Option C): Involves sexual arousal from touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person, unrelated to gender identity or clothing.

Gender dysphoria (Option D): Refers to distress caused by a mismatch between one's gender identity and assigned sex, which may or may not involve cross-dressing.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man reports that he derives sexual pleasure from being humiliated and physically harmed by his partner. He frequently seeks situations where he is beaten or degraded, and states that this pain excites him more than ordinary sexual activity. Which of the following best describes his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario of sexual gratification from humiliation and pain points towards masochism, where arousal is derived from experiencing pain or domination.

Masochism (Passive Algolagnia):

  • Opposite of sadism.
  • Sexual gratification is obtained or increased by experiencing pain.
  • Characteristics:
    • Pleasure derived from being beaten, abused, tortured, humiliated, enslaved, degraded, or dominated by a sexual partner.
    • Masochists may repeatedly place themselves in self-defeating situations.
    • Painful stimuli may completely replace ordinary sexual stimuli.
  • Epidemiology:
    • More common in males, but it also occurs in females.
    • Females may willingly expose themselves to severe injury or even death at the hands of brutal partners.
  • Demographics:
    • Found in all age groups and socioeconomic levels.
  • Role in Sexual Activity:
    • Acts of cruelty or pain may stimulate or completely replace sexual intercourse.

Explanation of other options:

Sadism (Option A): Involves deriving sexual pleasure from causing pain to others, not receiving it.

Fetishism (Option C): Involves arousal from objects or body parts, not pain or humiliation.

Transvestism (Option D): Involves dressing as the opposite sex for identity or arousal, without a focus on pain.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is arrested for attempting sexual intercourse with a corpse awaiting burial. Under Indian law, this act is punishable under which section of the IPC?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Necrophilia is punishable under Section 297 IPC with imprisonment up to 1 year and/or fine.

Necrophilia:

  • Desire for sexual intercourse with dead bodies.
  • Stimulants: Decomposition, foul smell, and coldness of the body.
  • Psychological factor: No danger of rejection or resistance from the partner.
  • Typical occurrence:
    • Usually committed on a newly buried corpse or a body awaiting burial.
    • The corpse may be mutilated following intercourse.
  • Murder for necrophilia: Very rare.
  • Legal aspect:
    • Punishable under Section 297, IPC (India).
    • Imprisonment up to 1 year and/or fine.

Explanation of other options:

Section 375 (Option A): Defines rape; applies to sexual intercourse with a living woman without consent, not a corpse.

Section 304 (Option C): Relates to culpable homicide not amounting to murder, unrelated to this case.

Section 377 (Option D): Previously criminalised unnatural sexual acts with humans or animals, but does not specifically address intercourse with a corpse.

choices.text: Pregnancy in a woman with German measles during first trimester
Pregnancy in a woman exposed to X-rays during pregnancy
Pregnancy due to maternal preference for child's gender

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for Medical Termination of Pregnancy under the MTP Act, 1971?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sex-selective abortion is illegal in India and is not a valid indication under the MTP Act, 1971.

Indications for MTP (MTP Act, 1971):

  1. Therapeutic:
    • When continuation of pregnancy endangers the life of the woman or may cause serious injury to her physical/mental health.
  2. Eugenic: (Risk of a child being born with serious physical or mental abnormalities)
    • If a pregnant woman in the first 3 months suffers from:
      • German measles (10-12% incidence of congenital defects) (Option B)
      • Smallpox or chickenpox
      • Toxoplasmosis
      • Viral hepatitis
      • Any severe viral infection
    • If treated with teratogenic drugs:
      • Thalidomide, cortisone, aminopterin, antimitotic drugs
      • Hallucinogens, antidepressants
    • If exposed to radiation:
      • X-rays or radioisotopes (Option C)
    • Insanity of the parents
  3. Humanitarian:
    • Pregnancy caused by rape. (Option A)
    • For a married woman: pregnancy caused despite the use of contraceptive methods, likely due to rape.
  4. Social:
    • Pregnancy due to failure of contraceptive methods in a married woman, likely to cause serious injury to her mental health.
  5. Environmental:
    • An adverse social or economic environment (actual or reasonably expected) that could injure the pregnant woman's health.

choices.text: Opinion of two doctors and husband's consent
Opinion of one doctor and her written consent
Opinion of one doctor and guardian's consent
Opinion of two doctors and guardian's consent

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to a government-recognised hospital seeking termination of pregnancy at 10 weeks of gestation. She is unmarried, states she is over 18 years old, and provides her written consent. Which of the following is the correct legal requirement to proceed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

For pregnancies <12 weeks, only the opinion of one registered medical practitioner is required, and the woman's own written consent is sufficient if she is over 18 years old.

Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) - Requirements:

  • Only a qualified registered medical practitioner can perform MTP:
    • Performed at least 25 cases of MTP OR
    • 6 months' experience after obtaining PG degree/diploma in Obstetrics & Gynaecology OR
    • Assisted as a house surgeon in the OBG department of a recognised hospital.
  • MTP can be performed only in:
    • Government hospitals
    • Government-recognized hospitals
    • Licensed private institutions (approved by district-level committee).
  • Consent:
    • Woman's written consent is mandatory.
    • Guardian's consent is required if the woman is a minor or mentally ill.
    • Husband's consent is not
    • Woman's statement of being over 18 years is accepted (no proof required).
  • Opinion requirements:
    • <12 weeks: opinion of 1 doctor.
    • 12-20 weeks: opinion of 2 doctors.

Explanation of other options:

Opinion of two doctors and husband's consent (Option A): Husband's consent is not required under the MTP Act, and two doctors' opinion is only needed for 12-20 weeks of gestation.

Opinion of one doctor and guardian's consent (Option C): Guardian's consent is needed only if the woman is a minor or mentally ill, which is not the case here.

Opinion of two doctors and guardian's consent (Option D): Incorrect because the woman is an adult, not mentally ill, and the pregnancy is under 12 weeks.

choices.text: Woman requesting abortion due to financial difficulties

questions.text: Which of the following is not an eligibility category for Medical Termination of Pregnancy between 20-24 weeks as per the MTP (Amendment) Act, 2021?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Financial difficulties alone are not listed as an eligibility category for 20-24 week termination under the MTP (Amendment) Act, 2021.

Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment), 2021:

  • Gestational Limits & Medical Opinion:
    • Up to 20 weeks of gestation:
      • MTP can be performed with the opinion of a single Registered Medical Practitioner (RMP).
    • Between 20 and 24 weeks of gestation:
      • MTP requires the opinion of two RMPs.
      • Applicable for the following specific categories:
        • Pregnancy due to rape, incest, or sexual assault. (Option A)
        • Minors. (Option B)
        • Change in marital status during ongoing pregnancy (e.g., widowhood, divorce).
        • Women with physical disabilities
        • Mentally ill women (including intellectual disability). (Option D)
        • Foetal malformation with substantial risk of:
          • Being incompatible with life OR
          • Severe physical/mental abnormalities causing a serious handicap.
        • Humanitarian settings, disasters, or emergencies declared by the government.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10470576/

questions.text:
You are working as a medical officer at a PHC. A 17-year-old girl presents after an alleged sexual assault and refuses to undergo physical examination. Which of the following steps should you take next as per the POCSO Act provisions?
1. Prophylaxis for sexually transmitted diseases, including HIV, should be offered.
2. It is mandatory to register a medico-legal case in all cases of child sexual abuse.
3. Medical examination must be performed regardless of consent in minors under 18 years.
4. Arrange a monthly follow-up for at least six months to check for the development of psychiatric disorders.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Consent is still required for examination of minors, but the doctor must register an MLC, offer STD prophylaxis, and ensure long-term psychiatric follow-up after a sexual assault under the POCSO Act.

POCSO Act, 2012 - Medical Examination & Care Provisions:

  • Medical examination of the child must be done in the least distressing manner.
  • Doctors should not demand completion of legal records/procedures or documentation before starting treatment or examination.
  • Legal procedures can be completed after initiating medical care.
  • Doctors must register a medico-legal case in all cases of child sexual abuse. (Statement 2)
  • Failure to report such cases can lead to six months' imprisonment and/or a fine under Section 21 of the POCSO Act, 2012.
  • Duties of the Registered Medical Practitioner:
    • Collect evidence after a thorough medical examination.
    • Treat physical and genital injuries.
    • Conduct an age assessment of the victim (if required).
    • Offer prophylaxis for sexually transmitted diseases, including HIV. (Statement 1)
    • Discuss emergency contraceptives with the pubertal child and her parent.
    • Perform baseline evaluation for mental health issues.
    • Arrange a monthly follow-up for at least six months to check for the development of psychiatric disorders. (Statement 4)
    • Provide family counselling.
    • Assist the court in interviewing the child and testifying in court.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4557243/

questions.text: Based on the given image below, under which section of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) is this offence punishable?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows unwanted physical contact/advances and sexual overtures by a man on a woman, which amounts to sexual harassment. Sexual harassment is punishable under Section 75 BNS.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is arrested for secretly watching women undress through their apartment windows. He reports intense sexual arousal during these acts but has never physically approached them. Which paraphilia does this behaviour represent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Voyeurism is a paraphilia characterised by sexual gratification from secretly observing unsuspecting individuals who are naked or engaged in sexual acts.

Paraphilia: Persistent abnormal sexual behaviour or fantasies involving unconventional objects or acts, leading to sexual gratification without intercourse.

questions.text: If the passive agent of sodomy is a child, the child is known as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

If the passive agent of sodomy is a child, the child is known as a Catamite.

  • Sodomy is anal intercourse between two males or between a male and female.
  • Sodomy is also referred to as buggery.
  • When the passive partner is an adult, the act is called gerontophilia.
  • When the passive partner is a child, it is called paederasty, and the child is known as a catamite.
  • A paedophile is an adult who repeatedly engages in sexual activities with children.

Explanation of other options:

Pederast (Option B): A pederast is the adult male who engages in sexual activity with a boy, not the child.

Dyke (Option C): A derogatory slang term used for a lesbian woman; unrelated to sodomy or children.

Femme (Option D): A term used in LGBTQ+ communities to describe a feminine-presenting person, usually lesbian; unrelated to sodomy or child sexual activity.

choices.text: Sexual gratification between men involving anal intercourse
Female homosexuality involving genital friction and manual stimulation
Sexual attraction of adults toward children
Sexual pleasure derived from watching others undress

questions.text: Tribadism refers to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tribadism:

  • Refers to female homosexuality; also known as lesbianism or sapphism.
  • Sexual gratification is obtained by a woman from another woman through:
    • Lip kissing and deep kissing
    • Generalised body contact
    • Manual manipulation of breasts and genitalia
    • Genital apposition and friction of external genital organs
    • Sucking of breasts or external genitalia
  • In some cases, an enlarged clitoris or an artificial penis (phallus) may be used.
  • External genitals may show signs of scratch marks, abrasions, or tooth marks.
  • Many lesbians are masculine in type, possibly due to endocrine disturbances.
  • They are often indifferent towards men (opposite sex).
  • Common among women who are mentally degenerate or suffer from nymphomania (excessive sexual desire).
  • Results from a combination of biological, psychological, developmental, and sociological factors.
  • May lead to sexual interference with young girls.
  • Lesbians with morbid jealousy may commit homicide, suicide, or both if rejected.
  • Tribadism is not an offence in India.

Explanation of other options:

Sexual gratification between men involving anal intercourse (Option A): This describes sodomy, a male homosexual act, not tribadism.

Sexual attraction of adults toward children (Option C): This defines paedophilia, which is unrelated to tribadism.

Sexual pleasure derived from watching others undress (Option D): This describes voyeurism, not tribadism.

questions.text: Penile buccal coitus is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Penile buccal coitus is known as Fellatio.
  • Fellatio (also called buccal coitus, coitus per os, fellation, or intercourse through the mouth) involves oral stimulation of the male sexual organs (penis and occasionally scrotum).
  • In buccal coitus, sexual gratification is obtained by introduction of the penis into the mouth of a female (heterosexual buccal coitus) or male (homosexual buccal coitus).
  • Also referred to as the Sin of Gomorrah historically.
  • Involves oral sex primarily targeted on the male genitalia.

Sadism (Option A): Sexual arousal through inflicting pain on another person - that is wrong.

Fetishism (Option C): Obtaining sexual arousal using or thinking about inanimate objects, materials, or parts of the body - that is wrong.

Cunnilingus (Option D): Oral stimulation of female sexual organs (clitoris, vagina, etc.) - that is wrong.

Key Takeaways:

  • Penile buccal coitus = Fellatio (oral stimulation of male genitalia).
  • Different from Cunnilingus, which involves female genitalia.
  • Sadism and Fetishism are distinct sexual behaviors unrelated to penile buccal coitus.

questions.text: Exhibitionism is punishable under which Section of BNS?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Section 296 BNS: Obscene acts and songs.
    • Whoever, to the annoyance of others, does any obscene act in any public place; or sings, recites or utters any obscene song, ballad or words, in or near any public place,
    • Shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to three months, or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
    • Exhibitionism falls under this section.
  • Section 74 BNS: Assault or use of criminal force on a woman with intent to outrage her modesty. (Option A ruled out)
    • Imprisonment for 1 to 5 years plus fine.
  • Section 79 BNS: Insulting the modesty of a woman.
    • Includes words, gestures, acts intended to insult modesty or intrude privacy.
    • Punishable with imprisonment up to 3 years plus fine. (Option B ruled out)
  • Section 292 BNS: Punishment for public nuisance in cases not otherwise provided for (e.g., Frotteurism).
    • Punishable with fine up to one thousand rupees. (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Exhibitionism is punishable under Section 296 BNS for obscene acts in public places.
  • Other sections address different offenses related to modesty and public nuisance.

choices.text: Death of the mother due to miscarriage
Preventing the child being born alive

questions.text: What does BNS Section 90 deal with?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Section 90 BNS: Death caused by an act done with intent to cause miscarriage.
    • (1) Whoever, with intent to cause the miscarriage of a woman with child, does any act which causes the death of such woman, shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
    • (2) If the act is done without the consent of the woman, punishment may extend to life imprisonment or the above-mentioned imprisonment.
  • Section 88 BNS: Causing miscarriage with consent, except to save the life of a woman.
    • Punishment up to 3 years or 7 years if a woman is quick with child, plus fine. (Option A ruled out)
  • Section 89 BNS: Causing miscarriage without woman's consent.
    • Punishment may be life imprisonment or imprisonment up to 10 years plus fine. (Option B ruled out)
  • Section 91 BNS: Act done with intent to prevent child being born alive or to cause death after birth.
    • Punishment up to 10 years imprisonment or fine or both. (Option D ruled out)
  • Section 92 BNS: Causing death of a quick unborn child by act amounting to culpable homicide.
    • Punishment up to 10 years imprisonment plus fine.

Key Takeaways:

  • Section 90 BNS specifically deals with death of the mother caused by miscarriage-related acts.
  • Other sections cover causing miscarriage with or without consent, preventing live birth, or causing death of the unborn child.

questions.text: A woman concealed the birth of her stillborn baby by secret disposal of the dead body. She is punishable under which section of BNS or BNSS?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Section 94 BNS: Concealment of birth by secret disposal of dead body.
    • Whoever, by secretly burying or otherwise disposing of the dead body of a child (whether the child dies before, after, or during birth), intentionally conceals or endeavors to conceal the birth of such child,
    • Shall be punished with imprisonment for up to two years, or fine, or both.
  • Section 93 BNS: Exposure and abandonment of a child under twelve years of age by a parent or person having care of it. (Option A ruled out)
    • Punishment may extend up to seven years imprisonment, or fine, or both.
  • Section 397 BNSS: Free treatment of victims of rape and acid attack.
    • All hospitals must provide free first-aid or medical treatment to victims and immediately inform the police. (Option C ruled out)
  • Section 456 BNSS: Commutation of sentence of death on pregnant women.
    • Death sentence shall be commuted to life imprisonment if the woman is found to be pregnant. (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Concealment of birth by secretly disposing of the dead body is punishable under Section 94 BNS.
  • Exposure/abandonment of a living child is covered under Section 93 BNS.
  • Sections 397 BNSS and 456 BNSS relate to victim treatment and sentencing, not concealment of birth.

choices.text: Disclosure of identity of victim of rape
Exposure and abandonment of child under twelve years of age
Concealment of birth by secret disposal of dead body

questions.text: What does Section 200 of the BNS deal with?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Section 200 BNS: Punishment for non-treatment of victim.
    • Whoever, being in charge of a hospital (public or private, run by Central Government, State Government, local bodies, or any other person), contravenes provisions of Section 397 BNSS,
    • Shall be punished with imprisonment up to one year, or fine, or both.
  • Section 397 BNSS: Deals with free treatment for victims of rape and acid attack and mandatory police notification of such incidents.
  • Other relevant sections:
    • Section 72(1) BNS: Punishment for disclosure of identity of victim of rape (up to 2 years imprisonment plus fine). (Option B ruled out)
    • Section 93 BNS: Exposure and abandonment of children under twelve years of age. (Option C ruled out)
    • Section 94 BNS: Concealment of birth by secret disposal of dead body. (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Section 200 BNS addresses failure by hospital authorities to provide mandated treatment to victims.
  • Related sections cover victim identity protection and offenses regarding children and birth concealment.
